text: CES Follow along with the Gizmodo crew as we take you on a by-the-minute tour of new tech on display at the annual Consumer Electronics Show. ¬© Gizmodo TVs? AI? Robots? Anthropomorphized robot lawnmowers? The Consumer Electronics Show (CES) has it all‚Äîand sometimes too much of it. We‚Äôve got boots on the ground at the year‚Äôs biggest tech event to wade through what‚Äôs relevant and interesting, no matter how unnecessary it might seem. We‚Äôll also highlight some of the weird, tacky, and weird-enough-it-just-might-work. Some companies have already debuted their wares before the show floor opens up. LG‚Äôs new three-in-one lamp-projector is an interesting amalgamation of devices for the living room, while Govee released a set of new pixel-ish gaming lights to make GIFs come to life. This robot vacuum is also piquing our interest because it does what other robot vacuums can‚Äôt, which is sprout a claw arm to pick up wayward objects. There‚Äôs much more to come, including major announcements from the industry‚Äôs biggest chipmakers and a whole lineup of new laptops and computers to consider shopping for later this year. Check back here for the most up-to-date news and hands-on impressions. Jan 10CES Impressed This Year After All ¬© Gizmodo That‚Äôs it! The live blog has ended. Thank you so much to everyone who stuck with us this week, clicked through for updates, and followed along as we brought you the weirdest, wackiest, and most relevant news from the enchanted land of Las Vegas. To start 2025, we saw many smart glasses and a resurgence of exciting computer peripheral technology. Laptops got thinner, of course, and they also got longer, in Lenovo‚Äôs case. Gaming handhelds are here to stay, with seemingly every favorite computer maker developing their mobile concoction. The weird stuff was interesting, too. The indoor gardening studio that won one of our favorites reminded us that all you need to grow is an ample water supply and lights to inspire. HiSense reminded us that appliances can match your home‚Äôs aesthetic. Companion robots are still on the CES show floor. Samsung and TCL drew passersby in with their respective ideas, though TCL‚Äôs was the cutest. Want to see it all? Scroll here. Or, head to the landing page to see the announcements made individually. It was a packed year and a little busier than we‚Äôd anticipated. That‚Äôs good news for gadgets in 2025. One more excellent take on Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang‚Äôs newfound fame to close us out: Jensen Huang Says Nvidia Is a ‚ÄòTechnology Company,‚Äô but It‚Äôs Really an AI Company Signing off, Kyle Barr, Florence Ion, Jorge Jimenez, Rose Pastore, and Sherri L. Smith Jan 10The Incredible Bending Gaming Monitor from LG ¬© Sherri L. Smith / Gizmodo LG is on a tear this year. If you‚Äôre bored with hearing about the company‚Äôs TVs, take a gander at its monitors. Namely, the LG UltraGear OLED Bendable Gaming Monitor. This is the world‚Äôs first bendable 5K2K gaming monitor. We played with it on the show floor and timed the transformation from flat to 900R curvature at 7.31 seconds. And oh my OLED, the colors are a cavalcade of rich hues and stunning blacks with crystal clear detail. And if that‚Äôs not enough special sauce, the monitor‚Äôs Dual-Mode feature got a nice upgrade, letting gamers switch seamlessly between presets for resolution, aspect ratio, and picture size. ‚ÄîSherri L. Smith Jan 10These Lenovo Monitors Can Track You So You‚Äôll Never Avoid Seeing or Hearing Your Screen ¬© Kyle Barr / Gizmodo Two concept monitors by Lenovo show us how, in the future, we may never be able to entirely turn away from our screens. The company‚Äôs ThinkCentre M90a Pro Gen 6 smart monitor uses technology from Audfly to track the user‚Äôs position in front of the screen and only blast the subject with audio. Anyone not being tracked by the monitor will barely hear a whisper, even when the subject receives a fuller sound experience. The sound quality wasn‚Äôt close to the HiFi audio you want for music, but it may work well for when you have a video meeting and don‚Äôt want to distract any deskmates.¬† The other concept monitor used computer vision to track whether the user moved to the left or right, keeping the user center-screen. It wasn‚Äôt particularly fast and wasn‚Äôt always 100% accurate, but it may work well enough if you‚Äôre a desk worker who can‚Äôt sit still. ‚ÄîKyle Barr Jan 10A Supersized Gaming Handheld PC from Acer ¬© Sherri L. Smith It seems that PC gaming handhelds are here to stay. And now Acer‚Äôs ready to jump into the mix with a couple of their own, the Acer Blade 8 and the massive Acer Blade 11. Sporting a ridiculous 10.95-inch, 2560 x 1600 resolution display with a 144Hz refresh rate, the Blade 11 is one of the biggest handhelds on the market. Dimensions aside, the Blade 11 also rocks an AMD Ryzen 7 8840HS with 16GB of RAM and up to 2TB of solid-state storage. Like the Lenovo Legion Go and Nintendo Switch, the Blade 11 has detachable joysticks and a kickstand. But the biggest surprise is that despite its size, the Blade 11 is very light at only 2.31 pounds. ‚ÄîSherri L. Smith Jan 10This Little Doodad Can Turn Any Game Into Sexy Time Have you ever thought: how can I make this video game sexy? Then worry not because Motorbunny, makers of straddle-style sex machines, has the answer. The company debuted the Fluffer PlayMate Plug-in Haptic Relay, a USB-C dongle that will change how you play video games. Plug the tiny gadget into the charging port of your PlayStation 5, Xbox Series S, or X controller (it also works with Nintendo Switch), and the PlayMate translates in-game actions into a haptic, rumbling sensation on a Bluetooth-connected Motorbunny sex machine for a more stimulating form of interactive play. Jan 10Meet the Overclockable Lawnmower ¬© Sherri L. Smith / Gizmodo We knew you could overclock CPUs and GPUs, but lawnmowers? Now we‚Äôve seen everything. But such is the case with the Litheli EasySurge 18.5-inch Lawn Mower. First, the design: The Litheli doesn‚Äôt look like any lawnmower I‚Äôve ever seen. It seems like it‚Äôd be more at home on The Jetsons than on the CES 2025 show floor. Even though the Litheli is small, it‚Äôs mighty. Thanks to the company‚Äôs proprietary EasySurge system, the mower‚Äôs motor can go from 1,000-1,200W with a speed up to 4,100 RPMs. You can also adjust the self-propelling speed, modify the mower‚Äôs cutting levels, and switch between cutting modes from the easy-to-use Surge panel. ‚ÄîSherri L. Smith Jan 10Acer Throws the Kitchen Sink and Then Some into Gaming Laptops ¬© Sherri L. Smith / Gizmodo When it comes to gaming laptops, more is better. Acer got the memo by refreshing the Predator Helios 18 and 16 AI laptops. Both systems have the new Intel Core Ultra 9 processor 275HX that boasts AI-accelerated performance. That‚Äôs joined by Nvidia‚Äôs latest powerhouse, the GeForce RTX 5090 GPU. Tricked out, the Helios 16 can accommodate 64GB of DDR5 RAM with a 4TB of PCIe Gen 5 SSD. But the Helios 18 said, ‚ÄúHold my beer,‚Äù and maxed out with a ludicrous 192GB of RAM and 6TB of storage. Display-wise, the 16-inch has an OLED panel with a 240Hz refresh rate, while the 18-inch goes 4K with a mini-LED screen with dual-mode resolution switching. We can‚Äôt wait to get our hands on these bad boys.‚ÄîSherri L. Smith Jan 10This Floor Lets You Fall Like a Ninja ¬© Sherri L. Smith / Gizmodo Fall injuries are no joke, especially for senior citizens. According to the CDC, in 2020, ‚Äúunintentional fall‚Äù death rates for adults aged 65 and over was nearly 71 per 100,000 population for men and almost 62 for women. However, the Japanese company Magic Shield has a solution, and we hope it will be stateside soon. The Shinobi Floor looks and feels like your average hardwood floor. Take a tumble, however, and you‚Äôll find a soft, springy feel instead of a cold, unforgiving floor. The patented shock-absorbing mat is placed directly beneath the floor, removing the impact‚Äôs force. So far, it‚Äôs been implemented in eight countries and 600 hospitals and senior centers. ‚ÄîSherri L. Smith Jan 10These Sex Toys Let You Reach Out and Touch Someone‚ÄîRemotely ¬© Sherri L. Smith / Gizmodo Lovense, purveyor of app-connected teledildonics, brought their latest wares to CES, and we‚Äôre intrigued. The Lovense Mission 2 and Solace Pro are a vibrating dildo and an AI-powered male masturbator that can be purchased together or solo. When paired together via the Lovense app, stroking the Mission 2 will cause the Solace Pro to move in tandem, matching the former stroke for stroke. It‚Äôs a cool way to have a sexy time when your lover isn‚Äôt in the vicinity. Fun fact: you can daisy chain up to 100 Lovense products, making it some of the safest sex you can have.‚ÄîSherri L. Smith Jan 10Now Your Favorite Anime Character Can Dance For You Ever wonder if Kakashi from Naruto or Kenpachi¬†from Bleach can bust a move? Now you can find out thanks to Code 27 Character Lightbox. Upload a 3D model of your favorite character, and you‚Äôll be off to the races. But Code 27 allows your character to be more than a dancing mascot. The character can turn and interact with you in real time by utilizing Freeform Large Language Models (LLM) and a rotating base with sound and sight recognition. It can even recall and summarize past interactions. It can also provide the day‚Äôs weather and offer conditions on your daily commute. Best of all, you aren‚Äôt confined to pre-existing characters, as Code 27 allows you to create your own unique characters.‚ÄîSherri L. Smith Jan 10The Weirdest Gadgets We Saw at CES 2025 ¬© Jorge Jimenez / Gizmodo Weird things are fun, and sometimes, they‚Äôre even helpful, like the N√©kojita FuFu. It‚Äôs a cute little device that hangs on your cup to help cool down a hot drink. The TCL Alme was another one of those weird things that caught our eye. Lenovo‚Äôs ThinkBook Plus Gen 6 Rollable, with its expandable laptop screen, also made the list. The Weirdest Gadgets We Saw at CES 2025 Jan 10Gizmodo‚Äôs Best of CES 2025 Awards ¬© Gizmodo JUST IN CASE you were wondering where we‚Äôre hosting our Best of CES 2025 awards, you can click the link below to get your fill. This year‚Äôs winners include the Lenovo Legion Go S, the XReal One Pro, and a mini washer-dryer combo from HiSense. Razer‚Äôs butt-cooling chair is also in the mix, as is LG‚Äôs portable display. Gizmodo‚Äôs Best of CES 2025 Awards: See the Winners Jan 10This Drone Can Fly in Any Direction and Roll Like a Tumbleweed ¬© Kyle Barr / Gizmodo What is the point of the HAGAMOSphere drone? The device is like your typical drone, though it has eight propellers mounted to a cubic frame, surrounded by rods and panels that allow it to contort to a ball-like shape. The frame is designed to roll along the ground or other rough terrain, with each panel meant to protect the drone from anything that would impact the propellers. I asked the designers of the ‚ÄúHybrid Autonomous Ground / Aerial MObility System‚Äù (hence, HAGAMOS) about its use cases, and they joked, ‚ÄúWe hoped you would tell us.‚Äù It could have applications in disaster response or construction, such as when you need a hardy drone that can survive rough or dangerous terrain. In my mind, I wonder how it might do for a few drone-based downhill races.¬† ‚ÄîKyle Barr Jan 10Jackery‚Äôs Solar Roof Panels Look Like Classic Roofing Tiles ¬© Kyle Barr / Gizmodo Solar tech company Jackery is promoting one of the most mundane-looking solar panels yet, enough that it might blend in with neighboring homes. The Jackery Solar Roof has curved blades and a modular design that allows it to stack on your roof like any traditional roofing tile. If you don‚Äôt mind heights, you may even be able to install them yourself. Jackery claims they can survive in temperatures between -40 and 185 degrees Fahrenheit. They also come with a 30-year warranty. As for their power efficiency, Jackery says its solar panels should offer more than 25% cell conversion, though what‚Äôs recorded in the lab is often worse than out in the field. We can‚Äôt verify any of those efficiency claims, though the aesthetic makes it a promising proposition for homeowners. ‚ÄîKyle Barr Jan 10The Hyve Pod Prevents Porch Pirates By Screaming When You Move it ¬© Kyle Barr / Gizmodo Hyve‚Äôs ‚Äúdelivery pod‚Äù is made to sit on your doorstop and provide a secure place for delivery drivers to secure your packages. The $300 device can be opened with a pin code or an app. This means you could include the pin with the shipping company in your delivery instructions, then hope the driver takes the time to open your pod and drop in your parcel. As for how it prevents porch pirates, the Hyve pod includes an accelerometer, so it knows to start blaring a sound if somebody moves it. There‚Äôs an additional cable to attach the box to a door frame, but that‚Äôs a last resort. You‚Äîand any Hyve-connected neighbors‚Äîare notified if somebody starts running down the street with it. ‚ÄîKyle Barr The Hyve Parcel Safe Prevents Porch Pirates By Screaming at Them Jan 10This Hiking Exoskeleton May Make Climbing Cliffs Too Easy ¬© Gizmodo Are you still considering the $5,000 MO/GO exoskeleton pants for hiking? Hypershell brought out its $800 Hypershell X hiking exoskeleton to CES 2025, promising that it can push your legs better and support backpack weight for long jaunts in the woods or mountains. The company sent us a pair early before CES, but the team was on the ground hooking people up to their own pair of robotic limbs. Like MO/GO, Hypershell X senses your leg movement and uses motors to propel your limbs forward with a 2ms response time. Hypershell promises it can boost your leg performance by up to 40%. It has several modes that provide a more subtle aid to your limbs. The device ranges up to 17.5 kilometers, or a little less than 11 miles on a single battery. The pants are up for preorder and should ship later this month.‚ÄîKyle Barr Jan 10Rock-ola Is Still Making Jukeboxes After 90 Years ¬© Jorge Jimenez / Gizmodo If you have ever been to a diner in the US at any point in your life, chances are you‚Äôve come across a Rock-ola Bubbler Jukebox. Well, Rock-ola is still rocking along after all. The modern Bubblers still have the retro look of the old Jukeboxes despite all the added bells and whistles. They can now connect to wireless home speaker systems like Sonos. While the Bubbles with a digital interface is convenient in this modern world, the models with physical music pages and vinyl record players can‚Äôt be beaten. If you‚Äôre wondering, one of these bad boys will set you back around $10,000. Jan 9Reolink‚Äôs Security Cameras Can Basically See in the Dark One common complaint about home security cameras is the bad video quality of the clips, especially in low-light environments. The new Duo 3 WiFi has a 180-degree Field-of-View (FoV) and uses AI motion detection to identify people and wildlife that may wander onto your property. The camera uses Reolink‚Äôs ColorX technology to see in the dark. You can see from the demo how the ColorX provides a surprisingly detailed picture of toy animals stuffed inside the dark box. ‚ÄîJorge Jimenez Jan 9My Favorite Character at CES 2025 Was Sassy VR Man Shiftall showed off its HaritoraX 1.1B wireless body tracking hardware that lets you control digital avatars with your entire body. This product is aimed at folks who use social VR games. I loved seeing this Shiftall employee bring to life the subtle nuances of being a sexy anime lady. ‚ÄîJorge Jimenez Jan 9Traffic Is Never an Issue When Your Motorcycle Can Turn Into a Quadcopter ¬© Jorge Jimenez / Gizmodo Rictor calls the X1-Rider ‚Äúthe world‚Äôs first amphibious passenger flying motorcycle.‚Äù It‚Äôs a bike that can sprout propellers. The rendered video shows the X1-Rider using automatic route planning to trace an optimal flight path before initiating its automated take-off process. Once airborne, you have a maximum flight speed of 100 km/h and a flight time of 40 minutes on its electric battery. The rider/pilot can either manually fly themselves or have the bike use its autopilot. A Rictor rep says we should see these on the road and in the skies in late 2026. While I am terrified of flying in this thing, I also really want to try it myself. ‚ÄîJorge Jimenez Jan 9This Sex Toy Works With Over 30,000 Pieces of Interactive Content Ohdoki is ramping up the interactivity with its latest gadget, the Handy. A sex toy designed for penis owners, the Handy consists of a silicon sleeve attached to a powerful brushless motor that can be adjusted by speed and stroke length. The device can be used either off or online via the companion app. It can also be enjoyed with VR content. Speaking of content, Handy owners will be spoiled with choices for content as the company reports there are 30,000 compatible videos out there to choose from. ‚ÄîSherri L. Smith Jan 9The Smart TV That Doubles as a Tablet and Much More ¬© Sherri L. Smith / Gizmodo LG makes a lot of TVs. There are some that bend, some that are wireless, and there are even a couple that you can see through. But the weirdest (and most delightful) televisions in the company‚Äôs stable are the StanbyMe line, particularly the StanbyMe 2. The StanbyMe 2 looks like a Smart TV and a tablet had a baby. The device has a massive 27-inch touchscreen and lasts four hours on a charge. And if you don‚Äôt feel like mounting it to a wall, you can connect the strap and carry it around like a massive purse, hang it vertically like a piece of art, or tuck it into a suitcase until you‚Äôre ready to watch. My favorite way to see the StanbyMe is by far the most outlandish. You can attach it to LG‚Äôs tripod with a speaker for rollable entertainment.‚ÄîSherri L. Smith Jan 9This Company is Selling the Apple Vision Pro‚Äôs Weird EyeSight Feature as its Own Thing ¬© Kyle Barr / Gizmodo The Apple Vision Pro‚Äôs external display uses something called ‚ÄúEyeSight‚Äù so people on the outside can see what you‚Äôre up to. B2B company EyeBliss enjoyed this about the Vision Pro, so it built it into its goggles and on a mannequin torso (seen here). The floating eyes in a black void certainly have a more lifelike appearance than the WeFace from the past two CESes, though I‚Äôm not sold on the idea that these electric eyes add any personality to isolating VR headsets. ‚ÄîKyle Barr Jan 9Monster Makes Smart Glasses Now, and They Actually Look Nice ¬© Jorge Jimenez / Gizmodo Monster is working on a line of smart glasses that look like something I‚Äôd actually put on my face. These specs primarily work as a Bluetooth headset with touch controls on the temples. I didn‚Äôt listen to music, but I was told you can get between 4 and 7 hours of listening time. Suppose you were expecting something to rival the Meta Ray-Bans. In that case, you might be slightly disappointed since these glasses can‚Äôt take pictures or video. However, Monster revealed that it‚Äôs working on a pair of smart AI glasses with a built-in camera and a translation feature. ‚ÄîJorge Jimenez Jan 9This $20,000 Gaming Pod Looks Like It Came From Outer Space ¬© Jorge Jimenez / Gizmodo Have you just wanted to game in your own little pod? Disconnected from the rest of the world? The XEO Pod might be up your alley. The XEO is a gaming chair enclosure that fully engulfs you. Neon lights surround you, and haptics are built into the seat so you can feel every explosion and impact travel up your spine. I fell in love with this thing and desperately wanted one for myself. Too bad it‚Äôs $20,000. ‚ÄîJorge Jimenez Jan 9This Little Gadget Could Inject Your Next Covid Shot, No Needle Required ¬© Rose Pastore / Gizmodo So many people suffer from needle phobia, and the medical waste created from single-use needles is staggering. A Dutch company called Flowbeams wants to solve both problems with a needle-free handheld injecting device. It uses lasers to shoot a stream of liquid (like a vaccine, insulin, tattoo ink, Ozempic, or Botox) into the skin at high speed, and there‚Äôs no biohazard waste to dispose of afterward. The company says it‚Äôs painless and that trials so far have shown it to insert the intended substance into the skin effectively. The device hasn‚Äôt been cleared by regulators yet, but Flowbeams aims to start with cosmetic injections and eventually move into medical use. ‚ÄîRose Pastore Jan 9Real-Time Space Weather Forecasts Thanks to Itty Bitty Satellites ¬© Rose Pastore / Gizmodo I met with a company called Mission Space that is working to increase the accuracy and timeliness of space weather forecasting. Solar storms can disrupt electric grids and satellite communications, including GPS, which affects air travel, agriculture, and many other vital industries. With a network of tiny satellites, Mission Space aims to offer real-time, precise space weather forecasts, providing space agencies, companies, and any other stakeholders a much clearer picture of when and where dangerous solar radiation may strike. ‚ÄîRose Pastore Jan 8Why Have a Birdfeeder With One Camera, When You Could Have a Birdfeeder With Two Cameras? ¬© Kyle Barr / Gizmodo Those who pass the time leering at the avian creatures enticed to your outdoor bird feeder may get annoyed when the wild beasts don‚Äôt pose for the camera. The Bird Buddy already does a good job analyzing species of birds that perch in front of its lens. However, for those flighty birds who won‚Äôt stay still, the Netvue Birdfy 2 Duo includes an additional camera to watch winged friends from the front and side with a wide-angle and portrait lens. The perch offers enough room for multiple birds at a time so that voyeuristic bird lovers can see various angles of a feeding frenzy. ‚ÄîKyle Barr Jan 8Panasonic Returns to the U.S. With OLED and LED TVs ¬© Kyle Barr / Gizmodo Late last year, Panasonic declared it was finally returning to the U.S. market for its TVs. The company started its American journey with just three mini-LED models. Panasonic is expanding on that with a wealth of new OLED and cheaper LED models. The flagship is the Z95B tandem OLED, which promises enhanced brightness due to the layered OLED panels. In person, it features the inky blacks and deep colors typical of these displays. The TVs feature a new backside with the rear subwoofers, which made for solid audio on last year‚Äôs flagship. There‚Äôs further promise that it is better at heat dissipation than the previous generation. ‚ÄîKyle Barr Jan 8Joel and Ellie from The Last of Us Were Running Security at the Sony Booth ¬© Gizmodo One of the longest lines at Central Hall at the Las Vegas Convention Center (LVCC) was at Sony, but it wasn‚Äôt to see a car, game console, or fancy TV. It was to snag a photo with two cosplayers dressed as Joel and Ellie from The Last of Us video games. I was told to look mean, so I did my best. ‚ÄîJorge Jimenez Jan 8This Quantum AI Security Camera Instantly Flagged Me as a ‚ÄúPerson of Interest‚Äù ¬© Gizmodo SK Technologies showed off its Quantum AI Camera, which works in tandem with live CCTV footage. The AI will scan crowds, instantly highlighting anything and anyone it deems suspicious, then alert security. Since this was a show floor demo, anyone who walked past it caught the attention of the AI. It‚Äôs not perfect since it flagged me twice, describing me as ‚Äúa man in leopard print coat walking‚Äù and ‚Äúa man in black mask riding a scooter.‚Äù I was not wearing a mask nor riding a scooter, so I think some things should best done with actual security personnel.‚ÄîJorge Jimenez Jan 8Hisense‚Äôs New 70‚Äôs-Style Washer-Dryer is Good for Diapers or Other Unmentionables ¬© Kyle Barr / Gizmodo What is this, a clotheswasher for ants? Hisense‚Äôs next miniature appliance seems to do it all, at least for your small loads of sensitive garments. The LuxCare mini washer-dryer uses microbubbles to clean clothing items more gently. It won‚Äôt fit your full load of dirty laundry in its tumbler, but for ‚Äúintimate and specialty fabrics‚Äù it should do a full wash and dry cycle in just under 80 minutes. The LuxCare could prove a timesaver for those with delicate clothes, but what helps sell it is the 1960s aesthetic.¬†‚ÄîKyle Barr Jan 8Xgimi Ascend Is a Massive Soundbar That Hides a 100-inch Roll-Up Projector Screen The Xgimi Ascend is a 2-in-1 ALR (Ambient Light Rejection) screen and soundbar. Inside the massive sound bar is a 100-inch motorized floor-rising screen. At a private demo at CES 2025, Xgimi told Gizmodo that if this product were to hit the market, it‚Äôd likely come bundled with the Aura 2 short throw 4K projector. You can adjust the screen to a smaller size for ambient mode when you‚Äôre not watching movies. I was treated to a nice little fireplace mode and a neat music mode. While just a prototype, I can easily see the Ascend appealing to folks looking for a 100-inch screen to watch movies without taking up an entire living room wall.‚ÄîJorge Jimenez Jan 8XReal‚Äôs New AR Glasses Make the Case That Real ‚ÄúSpatial Computing‚Äù Is Just Better Ultrawide ¬© Gizmodo CES 2025 is inundated with smart glasses. It takes a lot to stand out from the crowd, but XReal, a company that‚Äôs been in the augmented reality glasses game longer enough, showed off the XReal One Pro AR glasses. Effectively, the device is a tethered monitor for most mobile devices or PCs. Unlike similar glasses, the XReal One‚Äôs frames allow you to see your content in an ultra-widescreen view. It‚Äôs a feature akin to the ultrawide mirroring on the Apple Vision Pro or Meta Quest. The resolution is good enough to read small text without squinting. The glasses also include controls to change the size of windows you see through the AR environment. A single switch will also let you pin the mirrored window in space or have it follow your head. ‚ÄîKyle Barr Jan 8Honda and Sony Reveal Afeela Sedan¬† ¬© Rory Carroll / Gizmodo Honda and Sony jointly produced the Afeela 1 and Afeela 1 Signature sedans, officially available for pre-order in California. The EV will get at least 300 miles of range and level 2+ autonomous driving capability. The Afeela 1 starts at $89,900, and the Afeela 1 Signature Starts at $102,900.‚ÄîRory Carroll Jan 8Honda Reveals the Wild and Wedge-y 0 Series EV ¬© Rory Carroll / Gizmodo Honda was a little late to the electric car party, but it‚Äôs hoping to make a big impact with its radical 0 (‚Äúzero‚Äù) series EVs. The company showcased the two prototype cars at CES 2025 and they should be pretty close to what we‚Äôll see on the street in 2026. Honda‚Äôs Wild 0 Series EVs Slated for 2026 Jan 8Panasonic‚Äôs New Flagship Technics Earbuds Are Both New and Totally Old School ¬© Kyle Barr / Gizmodo CES is usually full of clamor and noise, but Panasonic‚Äôs new EAH-AZ100 earbuds offered a surprisingly high-quality reprieve from the usual din. Panasonic‚Äôs $300 flagship earbuds include the active noise canceling you expect, but it was good enough to block out all but a bare murmur from the chatter surrounding me. Panasonic claims its new ‚Äúmagnetic fluid driver‚Äù in the buds produces quality, low-distortion sound, and I was impressed with the sound quality from the few songs I listened to. Plus, the case is beautiful thanks to its brushed metal finish and inlaid Technics logo. It has an old-school quality that makes me want to hold onto the case rather than shove it deep in my pocket. ‚ÄîKyle Barr Jan 8Hisense First Commercial Micro-LED Display is a Sight for Sore Eyes ¬© Kyle Barr / Gizmodo Display technology is starting yet another shift. Mini-LED and OLED remain the standard bearers for high-quality TVs, but Hisense‚Äôs first micro-LED display promises excellent contrast and high brightness without backlights. The display technology is based on more than 24 million microscopic LEDs, each able to emit its own red, green, or blue light. It promises OLED levels of inky blacks without risk of burn-in or future degradation. The 136MX is the only model of three that will make its way to the U.S. It‚Äôs a big display, and even without pricing or release date info available, it‚Äôs the type of TV company that markets to folks with deep pockets. Ignoring the size, the picture quality is excellent and bodes well for more commercial micro-LEDs in the future.¬† ‚ÄîKyle Barr Jan 8The New Razer Blade 16 is Thinner, and Better for It ¬© Kyle Barr / Gizmodo The Razer Blade is one of those laptops you can always expect to be, at the very least, reasonably good quality, though all too expensive. Last year‚Äôs new Razer Blade 16 fit that mold, though it was similar to 2023‚Äôs model size, weight, and dreaded $3,000 starting cost. The design is identical in many ways, but now it‚Äôs 30% thinner and weighs less. That doesn‚Äôt sound like a lot, but holding it aloft, the changes feel far more significant. The ergonomics have also improved with easier key travel and a slightly smaller trackpad. Razer will pack it with the latest Nvidia RTX 50-series GPUs.
